title: June 2010 FQE - Paediatrics
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics (June 2010). Covers MCQs (True/False format converted to Multiple Select) and Essays.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Infective Endocarditis are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Never occurs in previously unhealthy heart
Prophylactic benzathine penicillin is necessary for prevention in rheumatic patients
Is associated with vegetation of the valves

questions.explanation: Infective endocarditis is primarily bacterial and involves vegetations. It can occur in healthy hearts (though less common). Penicillin prophylaxis prevents rheumatic recurrences, thereby preventing IE risk.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical presentations of Wilms' Tumour (Nephroblastoma)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Wilms tumor typically presents as a painless abdominal mass. Hypertension is common due to renin secretion. Fever and gross hematuria are less common presentations compared to Neuroblastoma.

questions.question: Select the correct statements defining Immunization.

options.text: The process of protecting a person from a specific disease
The process of immunity developing into infection
The process in which immunity occurs when a vaccine is given
The process in which the vaccine acts in place of a natural antibody

questions.explanation: Immunization protects against specific diseases by inducing immunity via vaccines.

questions.question: Which statement regarding Febrile Convulsions is TRUE?

options.text: It always follows some focus of infection (causing fever)
Fever is not necessary to make the diagnosis
It occurs before 6 months and after 6 years
There is always a history of head injury

questions.explanation: Febrile convulsions are triggered by a rapid rise in temperature due to infection (e.g., tonsillitis, otitis media) in the susceptible age group (6m-6y).

questions.question: Which of the following are metabolic disorders causing coma in children? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hypoglycemia, Electrolyte imbalance (Dehydration), and Toxins (Alcohol) are metabolic/toxic causes. Meningitis and Malaria are infectious causes.

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms/signs suggest Meningitis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All listed options are classic features of meningitis or meningeal irritation.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized causes of Cerebral Palsy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: CP can result from prenatal (IUGR), perinatal (Asphyxia, Prematurity), or postnatal (Meningitis, Haemorrhage) brain injury.

questions.question: Regarding Epilepsy management, which statements are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Violent muscular activity should not be restrained
Metabolic disorders and intoxication must be excluded
Intravenous access is optional in status epilepticus
Long term treatment may be similar to complex convulsions
Phenobarbitone 10-20 mg/kg loading dose may be used

questions.explanation: IV access is mandatory in status epilepticus. Restraining can cause injury. Metabolic causes must be ruled out.

questions.question: Concerning Acute Childhood Diarrhoea, which statements are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Is most common below the age of one year

questions.explanation: Most cases are viral (Rotavirus). Antibiotics and anti-motility drugs (Kaolin) are generally contraindicated. Convulsions can occur from febrile seizures or electrolyte imbalance.

questions.question: What is included in the management of acute diarrhoea with NO dehydration (Plan A)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: 10 mls/kg of ORS after each loose stool

questions.explanation: Plan A involves home fluids, Zinc, and replacing losses (10ml/kg per stool). 75ml/kg is Plan B.

questions.question: Which problems are associated with Infants of Diabetic Mothers (IDM)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: IDMs are large, have immature lungs (RDS), and get jaundice. They typically have Polycythemia, not Anaemia.

questions.question: Select the relevant investigations for a child with suspected Meningitis.
questions.explanation: All listed investigations are relevant for diagnosing the cause and complications of meningitis.

questions.question: Mwanahamisi (3yo) has loose, mucoid, blood-stained stools. Her mother gave plain water. Select the TRUE statements about her condition.

options.text: May develop hyponatraemia (due to plain water)
Giardia lamblia is a likely causative organism
Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites likely in stool

questions.explanation: Bloody/mucoid stool suggests Dysentery (Amoeba/Shigella). Plain water intake dilutes sodium (Hyponatremia). Diarrhea loses potassium (Hypokalemia).

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical prognostic indicators in Perinatal Asphyxia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Prognosis depends on the severity of the insult (APGAR, HIE stage) and the resilience of the baby (Weight). SES is a risk factor, not a direct clinical prognosticator of the injury itself.

questions.question: Which vaccines can be safely given to a symptomatic HIV positive child?
questions.explanation: Killed/Toxoid vaccines (Pentavalent, Hep B, TT) are safe. Measles is usually given despite being live (benefits outweigh risks) unless severely immunosuppressed. Yellow Fever (Live) is generally contraindicated in symptomatic HIV.

questions.question: Select the MAJOR criteria in the Jones system for Acute Rheumatic Fever.
questions.explanation: Major criteria: Joints, O (Carditis), Nodules, Erythema Marginatum, Sydenham's Chorea. Erythema Nodosum is NOT a criterion.

questions.question: Heavy proteinuria is indicative of:
questions.explanation: Massive proteinuria is the hallmark of Nephrotic Syndrome.

questions.question: Select the TRUE statements regarding Post-term babies.
questions.explanation: Post-term babies are 'overcooked': Dry/peeling skin, long nails, no vernix, no lanugo.

questions.question: Which of the following are Acyanotic Congenital Heart Diseases? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: VSD and PDA are left-to-right shunts (Acyanotic). TGA, Tricuspid Atresia, and TOF are Cyanotic.

questions.question: Which drugs are useful in a 10-year-old with Severe Status Asthmaticus? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Steroids and Bronchodilators are key. Epinephrine is used for severe/anaphylactic asthma. Diazepam is contraindicated (respiratory depression).

questions.question: Arrange the first 6 steps of WHO management of Severe Acute Malnutrition (Stabilization Phase) in order:
questions.explanation: Sugar -> Warmth -> Fluids -> Electrolytes -> Infection -> Micronutrients -> Feeding.

questions.question: Select the possible complications of Phototherapy. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Phototherapy can cause fluid loss, overheating, eye damage, and skin issues.
